content:
If you are a developer who uses Angular with Angular command-line interface (CLI), then almost every day you are probably asking yourself, ‘Is there some way I can extend Angular CLI a little bit to fit my needs?’ 

I did this several times before getting to it. 

Having gone into the Angular CLI repository I found that it uses angular/devkit for file generation. I have also discovered that angular/devkit uses schematics for generating a tree (representing a file-folder structure) from a tree provided by the @schematics/angular package. 

So, knowing this I was pretty sure that @schematics/angular would help a lot to get where I wanted to go with the changes I want to make. Before writing I try to research if someone else has already found a way to do what I want so I can skip the ‘head-banging on the wall’ part of development. 

At the outset, I thought it would be a common thing that everybody uses and there would be hundreds of articles on ‘how to build your own schematic package’ and how to integrate it in Angular CLI. Unfortunately, I could only find two articles showing a little bit of how this can be accomplished. 

The first was written by [Philippe Martin](https://blog.angularindepth.com/creating-your-own-application-template-for-angular-cli-95e22319cc24) where he explains how to build your own application template and the other article was written in some tutorial site (and I can’t find it at the moment). Neither of them explained exactly what I needed so I decided to implement my own package. Let me walk you through the process of what I did to get there. 

The first steps are to:

- Initialize a repository in GitHub
- Create a new application with Angular CLI
- Create a brand new npm package (node package manager) called ‘@schematics/custom’

The first step is pretty easy and [here](https://help.github.com/articles/create-a-repo/) is a tutorial on how to do it.

After cloning the repository on my computer I execute into the folder of the repository

> ng new foo

and my second step is finished.

The third step is a little bit difficult to understand if you are not familiar with NPM packages and how they work.

People might not know they can create a local NPM package and install it by providing a folder location of a package without publishing into any npm server. So after knowing this I create and install a local NPM package with these commands

> mkdir schematics -> creates a folder

> npm init -f  -> initializing the NPM package

> cd ../foo -> getting back to the angular application

> npm install ../schematics --save-dev -> installs the package into the angular application

I have a brand new empty NPM package installed into my _foo_ angular-cli project.

Now I have to do a little change in my package.json file of the schematics package so when I install the package I would like to find it in __node_modules/schematics__ folder of the _foo_ application. In this folder are located the original angular schematics.

I am going to my schematics package folder. Opening the package.json file and I am changing the __name__ property value to be **_@schematics/custom_**

![](https://blog.bbogdanov.net//images/angular-schematics-package/schematics-second.png)

Let's continue...

Now I will copy the _component_ folder and some utils files from the official _@schematics/angular_  package to my __@schematic/custom__ package.At the moment my repo (repository) looks like this:

![](https://blog.bbogdanov.net/images/angular-schematics-package/schematics-third.png)

Where ones again the _foo_ folder is the brand new angular-cli application and the ‘schematics’ folder represents my custom schematics package.
Now let add some files to the custom component. I am going to add two files - 

> ____name@dasherize____Actions.ts

and

> ____name@dasherize____Reducer.ts

![](https://blog.bbogdanov.net/images/angular-schematics-package/schematics-fourth.png)

I am not going into too many details why all of the names have prefix **____name@dasherize____**. It is part of schematics and helps the naming of the files when they are generated.

We are ready to test it so, let's go!

1. Installing the package in the angular-cli application via:

> npm install ../schematics –save-dev

2. Running in the angular-cli application folder:

> ng g c test –collection=@schematics/custom

but unfortunately, there is an error about missing packages like typescript, rxjs and so on in the compiled. 

Let's install these packages and try again.

![](https://blog.bbogdanov.net/images/angular-schematics-package/schematics-fifth.png)

Repeating step one and step two and.....

Congratulations we successfully created a custom schematics package.

If there is a need to set the custom collection by default, there is a command-line which can help with that:

> ng set defaults.schematics.collection @schematics/custom

or just edit the **.angular-cli.json** file.

My work is available on [GitHub](https://github.com/bbogdanov/angular-with-custom-schematics) and is also under the **MIT license** so feel free to use it if you need it. 

I hope this helps!

Thanks once again to the Angular team for making such great software!

content:
Every IT project has development processes. One of the main processes is the **_implementation_** one. ITIL(Information Technology Infrastructure Library) is known as the **_Application Development _** process. Unfortunately, the process has no defined steps which you can follow and that's what I am going to define and give hints on why.

The steps are **three** and they are:

 - Development
 - Unit testing
 - Continuous integration


Before you begin with the code implementation, you need to be aware of how changes are going to be managed. You need a well-defined **Change Managment**. There are a lot of source control services like [GitHub](https://github.com), [Bitbucket](https://bitbucket.org/), [Visual Studio Team Services](https://www.visualstudio.com/) that can help your organization or team to manage the code of the product. Also, you need a well-defined strategy on how to use these source control services through the process.

### **Development**

The **Development** step is to implement new functionality into the product. In this step, you write some code, and if it works you store it to the main code store or code repository.

The need of owning a good development environment is necessary for this step because as a developer you need to feel comfortable while working. Nowadays the tools that you need to develop a functionality are to have an [IDE](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integrated_development_environment) and a [debugger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Debugger) which runs your code and you can see live what your code is doing. When the functionality is ready it has to be pushed to the code repository. Before the push, you have to do some basic steps and they must be already defined in the Code management process where your code process strategy is implemented and best practices are written.

So let's say your code is pushed to the main repository but your changes broke one feature functionality because you changed one function implementation. Well obviously you have to go and fix it, but can you prevent that from happening in the future? Yes and here it comes the** unit testing** part.

### **Unit testing**

So when we need to talk about **a good **implementation process, we definitely have to mention the testing part. There are two types of testing - unit, and integration. There is a big difference between unit and integration testing and there are many books like [The Art of Unit Testing ](https://www.amazon.com/Art-Unit-Testing-Roy-Osherove/dp/1617290890/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1504868023&sr=8-1&keywords=the+art+of+unit+testing) where this difference is explained and shown by examples.

There are also two types of how you can test units - manual and automatic. In this post, I will talk about the automatic ones.

It is so boring to test manually every single time before committing your changes if something in the project has been broken after your functionality implementation.

Let's say your project is like 30000 code long. Before each commit, you have to spend 5 or more hours to test if all functions are doing their job correctly manually. It will feel like...

![](https://blog.bbogdanov.net//images/product-implementation/old-man-time-watch.jpeg)

So we have to automate them. There is at least one testing framework for every modern language which gives you the opportunity to test your units like [NUnit](http://nunit.org/), [JUnit](http://junit.org/junit4/), [Jasmine](https://jasmine.github.io) and so on.

By testing your units you will be able to keep track of the product functionality. Let's say someones broke or changed the functionality of a single unit. You will understand right after running the unit tests that a unit functionality has been changed because the unit test will fail. If a unit test fails, you know a function is broken and better check where this unit has been used.

## Test your units to protect yourself from creating issues. 

Also, the unit test protects you from creating too much dependent functionality. Let's say a single unit test is like 100 lines of code long and also includes 2 or more assert functions. Like I said previously, there are two types of testing - unit testing and integration testing. If a unit test tests more than one single function is more acquired to be an integration test.

I wrote a quick example in [Plunker](https://plnkr.co/edit/6qyDf0) for how integration test and a unit test could look like.

Right after your unit tests are done you are good to commit your changes into the official code repository.

After the commit, you have to spend like 30 minutes to go build the application and deploy it on your company product test environment so the QAs could check if the functionality you created works as expected and meet business requirements. But why you have to spend 30 or more minutes every time when you change the functionality or create one to build and deploy it in the test environment? Can you automate this process? Yes and here it comes the **continuous integration** part.

### **Continuous Integration**

Continuous integration will help you to create an effective and well-defined deployment process. But In this post, I will not talk about the entire deployment process because it is defined at **Release and Deployment Management**  process of ITIL. I am going to discuss the part of the deployment process which is related to the application development work.

After every commit, the CI should run automatically and this is the great part. It should build the product and run the unit tests ones more to check if your application is good to continue with the deployment part.

The computers are like humans - they make mistakes and sometimes on your computer, the application built correctly but on the CI machine didn't. If something is going wrong on the CI machine it means that the deployment process is not correct and well-defined and you have to fix it.

One way of removing the possibility of the application to be built correctly on your machine, but not on the CI one is to use [Docker](https://www.docker.com/). Anyway, it is a good practice the CI to do the build and run the unit tests one more time to ensure the product is going to be deployed correctly, but if the build fails, the deployment process will not be triggered and you will not deploy a broken product and that is great because the client will not see a broken product on his production environment where real people might work or use the product!

So after all what are these three steps after all giving us:

![](https://blog.bbogdanov.net/images/product-implementation/application_development_process.png)

- Development process - When following the change management process, you will create fewer conflicts when committing and do not actually commit to covering with tests the functionality you already created.
- Unit tests - Less broken pieces in the product implementation, run them before committing the changes into the main repo, so you prevent broken features to go into the main repository and also prevent the CI to fail the build step. Time-saving.
- Continuous integration - Ensures your project is ready to continue with the deployment in the test environment where the QAs can check the newest functionality. Time-saving.

I will keep developing this article so if you have any suggestions what steps could be added to the **Application Development** process, feel free to share it in the comments.

Special thanks to [Jordan Georgiev](https://www.linkedin.com/in/jordangeorgiev/), [Yani Popov](https://www.linkedin.com/in/yani-popov-82070032/) and [Petar Ivanov ](https://www.linkedin.com/in/petar-ivanov-3453655b/) for helping me create this post.

Thank you for reading the article!
